revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox settlement |name= Hollywood Hills |official_name= |nickname= |native_name= |settlement_type=[[Neighborhoods in Los Angeles|Neighborhood of Los Angeles]] |motto= |image_skyline= View towards Hollywood Sign and Hollywood Hills, Los Angeles.jpg |imagesize= 300px |image_caption= The Hollywood Hills and the [[Hollywood Sign]] |image_map = Map of the Hollywood Hills district of Los Angeles.png |map_caption = Map of the Hollywood Hills neighborhood of Los Angeles,
as delineated by the ''Los Angeles Times'' |pushpin_map=United States Los Angeles Central |pushpin_label_position=right |pushpin_map_caption=Location within Central Los Angeles |pushpin_mapsize=250 |coordinates = {{coord|34.12|-118.34|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] | subdivision_name = {{flag|United States}} | subdivision_type1 = [[U.S. state|State]] | subdivision_name1 = {{flag|California}} |subdivision_type2 = City |subdivision_name2 = [[Los Angeles]] |subdivision_type3 = |subdivision_name3 = |elevation_ft=1,260 |elevation_footnotes=https://elevation.maplogs.com/ }} The '''Hollywood Hills''' is a hillside neighborhood in the [[Central Los Angeles|central]] region of the city of [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. __TOC__ ==Geography== [[File:Los Angeles from Hollywood Hills.jpg|thumb|left|Los Angeles from Hollywood Hills]] The Hollywood Hills straddle the [[Cahuenga Pass]] within the [[Santa Monica Mountains]]. The neighborhood touches [[Studio City]], [[Universal City, California|Universal City]] and [[Burbank, California|Burbank]] on the north, [[Griffith Park]] on the north and east, [[Los Feliz, Los Angeles|Los Feliz]] on the southeast, [[Hollywood]] on the south and [[Hollywood Hills West]] on the west. It includes [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]], the [[Hollywood Reservoir]], the [[Hollywood Sign]], the [[Hollywood Bowl]] and the [[John Anson Ford Amphitheatre|John Anson Ford Theater]].[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/region/central-la/ "Central L.A.," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''][http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/region/hollywood-hills "Hollywood," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''][http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/region/san-fernando-valley "San Fernando Valley," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times'']''The Thomas Guide,'' 2006, pages 563 and 593 Hollywood Hills is bisected southeast-northwest by [[U.S. Route 101 in California|US 101]]. The neighborhood is bounded on the northwest and north by the Los Angeles [[city limits|city line]], on the east by a [[fireroad]] through Griffith Park, continuing on [[Western Avenue (Los Angeles)|Western Avenue]], on the south by [[Franklin Avenue (Los Angeles)|Franklin Avenue]] and on the west by an irregular line that includes Outpost Drive. Bedrock of the Hills is a complex association of [[granitic]] and [[metamorphic]] rock plus interbedded [[sandstone]] and [[shale]] on which brown loamy soil, often shallow and with abundant stones, has developed.{{Cite web|url=https://casoilresource.lawr.ucdavis.edu/gmap/|title=SoilWeb: An Online Soil Survey Browser {{!}} California Soil Resource Lab|website=casoilresource.lawr.ucdavis.edu|access-date=2020-01-28}} ==Neighborhood== The neighborhood of Hollywood Hills includes the [[Hollywood Bowl]] and [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Hollywood Hills|Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)]] as well as two private and three public schools. Hollywood Hills contains several neighborhoods:[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/neighborhood/hollywood-hills "Hollywood Hills," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''] {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Laurel Canyon, Los Angeles|Laurel Canyon]] *[[Beachwood Canyon, Los Angeles|Beachwood Canyon]] *[[Cahuenga Pass]] * Franklin Village *[[Hollywood Dell, Los Angeles|Hollywood Dell]] * [[Hollywood Heights, Los Angeles|Hollywood Heights]] * Hollywoodland *[[Outpost Estates, Los Angeles|Outpost Estates]] *[[Whitley Heights, Los Angeles|Whitley Heights]] {{div col end}} ===Population=== 21,588 people lived in the neighborhood's 7.05 square miles, according to the 2000 U.S. census—averaging 3,063 people per square mile, among the lowest [[population density|population densities]] in the city or the county. The population was estimated at 22,988 in 2008. The median age for residents was 37, considered old for the city and [[Los Angeles County|the county]]. The percentages of residents aged 19 through 64 were among the county's highest. The neighborhood has a [[diversity index]] of 0.433, and the percentage of [[Non-Hispanic Whites]] is 74.1%. [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latinos]] make up 9.4%, [[Asian American|Asians]] are at 6.7%, [[African American]] at 4.6% and others at 5.3%. In 2000, [[Mexico]] (7.9%) and the [[United Kingdom]] (7.8%) were the most common places of birth for the 22.8% of the residents who were born abroad, which was considered a low percentage of foreign-born when compared with the city or county as a whole.[http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/diversity/neighborhood/list/#hollywood-hills "Diversity," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''] The median household income in 2008 dollars was $69,277, considered high for the city but about average for the county. The percentage of households earning $125,000 or more was high, compared to the county at large. The average household size of 1.8 people was relatively low. Renters occupied 56.5% of the housing units, and homeowners the rest. In 2000, there were 270 families headed by single parents, or 6.9%, a rate that was low in both the county and the city. ===Education=== In 2000, 54.8% of residents aged 25 and older held a four-year degree, considered high when compared with the city and the county as a whole. There are five secondary or elementary schools within the neighborhood's boundaries:[http://maps.latimes.com/neighborhoods/neighborhood/hollywood-hills/schools/ "Hollywood Hills Schools," Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''] * Immaculate Heart High and Middle School, private, 5515 Franklin Avenue * Valley View Elementary School, [[LAUSD]], 6921 Woodrow Wilson Drive * The Neilson Academy, private, 2528 Canyon Drive * Cheremoya Avenue Elementary School, LAUSD, 6017 Franklin Avenue * The Oaks, private elementary, 6817 Franklin Avenue The [[American Film Institute]] is at 2021 North [[Western Avenue (Los Angeles)|Western Avenue]][http://projects.latimes.com/mapping-la/neighborhoods/neighborhood/hollywood-hills/?q=American+Film+Institute%2C+2021+North+Western+Avenue%2C+Los+Angeles%2C+CA+90027%2C+USA&lat=34.1075984&lng=-118.3099624&g=Geocodify Mapping L.A., ''Los Angeles Times''] ===Recreation and culture=== The neighborhood includes: * The [[Hollywood Bowl]] * The [[John Anson Ford Amphitheatre]] * A portion of [[Griffith Park]], including Hollywoodland Camp * [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]] ==Notable people== {{More citations needed section|date=February 2020}} {{div col|content= * [[Christina Aguilera]], singer, songwriter, actresss * [[Earle D. Baker]] (1888–1969), Los Angeles City Council member[https://search.proquest.com/docview/156263968 "Services Slated for Ex-Councilman Baker," ''Los Angeles Times,'' July 17, 1969, page residence of the Baker family on ''Mapping L.A.''] * [[Jolene Blalock]], actress[https://variety.com/2013/dirt/real-estalker/update-rapino-sells-to-faris-and-pratt-1201235767/ Variety] * [[Gisele
